I was one of the engineers working on the Buran project. The official reason for the end of the project is "cease of funding", but actually it wasn't. On the final approach, we had no way of controlling it from the ground and suddenly at around 11km it just turned 180 degrees and started flying in opposite direction. The reason was that the computer received new wind data and recalculated landing trajectory, landing from the other end of the runway. Nobody understood it tho and we were just a minute away from shooting it down with a rocket believing it was a malfunction. After that government decided that the shuttle was unsafe and the program got canceled. Btw, until around 2010 all information was highly classified, and right after the incident almost all magnetic tapes with flight data recordings were... destroyed. Fine, lost according to official version :\

P.S. Pronouncation: "Booran" and "enirgia"

These must be the most painful of cancellations. To actually prove the system can work, only for it to be scrapped for reasons that have little to do with it.

Moreso than one which at least has the consolation of not actually succeeding in making it to LEO.

I of course speak of the likes of Europa - which again marks a Classic British Inability to think long-term - which was basically a Hodge-Bodge of different rockets all in a line, for which only the British Blue Streak consistently worked...before the UK pulled out and the rest of what would become the ESA would learn from it and, well, you know the rest.

And obviously the "Stop Exploding you Fool!" N1. Cancelling that must've been one of Glushko's easiest tasks...

Back to topic. While in many ways an improvement over STS - smaller so-called Black Zones as far as I can tell for one - Buran was also a Manned Orbiting System that lacked a mission IMHO, with that plus Soyuz still being available, it's cancellation I think was to be expected with the fall of the USSR, if still bitter. Energia itself at least had one small advantage on account of being its own Superbooster - Buran being just a payload in this sense - so could have supported BEO Missions...had there been any money, and Political Will, for it.

But perhaps its most tragic detail? Energia/Buran was itself a symptom of a far more serious problem with the USSR, one that eventually brought it down.

On pronunciation:
Russian is a very phonetic language, so for the most part, unlike English, the letters are pronounced very literally based on their names.
Buran (Бура́н) is pronounced "Byoorawn" as Russian does not have a hard A sound like that in "cat". Emphasis is on the "ah" sound due to the accent mark.
Energia ( Энергия) is pronounced "Enyerghiya". the Э is "Eh", the e is "yeh", the г is a hard G as in "Get", and the я is "Yah".

Delta III is another one. I worked on Delta III. In parallel with Delta III, Delta IV preliminary design was going on to win the future EELV contract. Boeing won a good portion of EELV and Delta IV went forward into production. 
Delta III had a launch failure in its 1st launch, an issue with its Aerojet RL-10 on its second flight but did have a successful launch of a dummy payload on its third launch. Then it was cancelled and replaced by Delta IV. However many of the Delta III products like upper stages and fairings were used on Delta IV. Delta III utilized a lot of composites and provided an experience base in designing composite launch vehicle structures to Delta IV.
The knowledge gained by all of us on the Delta III design team that switched to Delta IV provided good launch vehicle development experience to the Delta IV team.

Russian pronunciation seems hard, but ends up being easy.
Буран энергия looks scary, but the sounds of the letters in Russian pretty much always stay the same so once you learn them there are very few new rules to learn.
B oo r ah n, en er gee yah
The g is always hard as in gift (or gif)
If they want the soft g sound they'd use ж (jh) or Дж (d jh)
The r is rolled, because it's fun and English Rs are hard.
